On 02/06/2006 02:21 PM, Cédric Beust ♔ apparently said:
> On 2/6/06, Jason Rogers <jacaetevha@...> wrote:
> >
> > Not if your refactoring tool operates on an AST. Nodes on the AST have
> > context which the refactoring tool should take into consideration.
>
>
> No, the AST can't help you there because it has zero type information.
>
> Consider this example:
>
> def f(o)
> o.init()
> end
>
> def g(o)
> o.init()
> end
>
> You rename init to init2, how can the IDE know which ones needs to be
> renamed?
>
> It can't. Nobody can.

You can use Type Inference. When Type Inference yields ambiguous 
responses the tool ought to make you aware of it and give you the 
opportunity to cancel or make a logical choice between the inferred 
types. Type Inference is not so ethereal as some would think. Squeak, 
for instance, has an implementation (though not very performant at the 
moment).

>
> It's one of the reasons why Duck Typing is
> dangerous<http://www.beust.com/weblog/archives/000269.html>

I disagree with your article, but again that's a topic for another 
group/list.

-- 
Jason Rogers
